Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A critical bearing is screeching loudly and threatening an immediate breakdown.
Story:
I could hear the screeching from the factory floor before I even reached the break room. My phone buzzed in my pocket—another alert from the maintenance system, warning me that the main conveyor’s bearing was about to fail. I knew what that meant: if I didn’t get to it soon, the whole line could go down, costing hours of production and a mountain of stress for everyone.

But as I stepped into the break room to grab my tools, I saw him—my boyfriend—slumped at the table, eyes red, shoulders hunched. He’d just gotten that feedback from his boss, the one he’d been dreading all week. He looked up at me, searching for comfort, for the girlfriend who always listened, always made things better.

My mind raced. I could see the expectation in his eyes, the silent plea for me to sit, to hold his hand, to be there for him. But the factory’s alarms echoed in my ears, reminding me of my duty, the trust everyone placed in me to keep things running. My heart twisted, caught between the person I loved and the job I couldn’t ignore.
